page.title: 03Local History Deane&Daubhill
page.content: {Deane}was a large parish containing many townships. The present Parish Church was built in 1452, although the earliest record of the chapelry dates back to 1100. A stone cross in the churchyard commemorates the martyrdom of George Marsh, Vicar of Deane, who was burned at the stake at Chester in 1555 for refusing to acknowledge "Romish" doctrines. { {Daubhill}- referred to in Bolton dialect as "Dobble" - derives from the old English word{daub,}meaning clay. This area of Bolton was an important centre for brickmakers during the 19th century, when many houses were needed for the rapidly expanding population of the Industrial Revolution. Prior to this, it was a rural area.
